title: RC circuits - 2 Rs and 1 C - initial current in R2

content.question: In the circuit shown, the switch is initially open and the capacitor is initially uncharged. Then the switch is closed. Which of the following correctly describes the current in Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> immediately after the switch is closed, and provides reasoning that supports the claim?

choices.label: It is zero. Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is in parallel with the capacitor, which has no charge initially.
It is zero. A resistor in parallel with a capacitor behaves as an open circuit initially.
It is nonzero. Closing the switch establishes a potential difference across Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.
It is nonzero. Initially, none of the current in the circuit goes through the capacitor branch.

content.answer: It is zero. Resistor <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>R</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is in parallel with the capacitor, which has no charge initially.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
